item.title: Europe Cannot Avoid an AI Reckoning
item.description: Given the risks it faces from all sides, Europe must move past its focus on regulatory excellence. Unless it makes rapid strides toward building the physical and financial infrastructure that a domestic European AI industry will need, such preoccupations will prove to be more of a liability than an asset.

item.title: The Super Bowl of Prediction Markets
item.description: As prediction markets have exploded onto the scene in recent years, allowing bets to be placed on a wide range of event-driven outcomes, many have asked whether it is optimal to have markets in everything. But the real question is how best to ensure that these powerful tools are transparent and auditable.

item.title: Brother Trump
item.description: US President Donald Trump has demonstrated how quickly democratic politics can be overtaken by intimidation and cruelty. As Thomas Mann argued in the early 20th century, authoritarians gain power because they activate dispositions that already exist within democratic societies.

item.title: Timing Africa’s Debt Restructuring
item.description: In 2025, sovereign-debt sustainability was largely a matter of luck. In 2026, governments and creditors must embrace a new framework for action on debt – one that identifies and addresses hidden debt issues before they spiral out of control, and delivers restructuring agreements fast enough to offer genuine relief.

item.title: Trump Is Not All Wrong About Mexico
item.description: Since intervening in Venezuela, US President Donald Trump has escalated his threats to use direct military action against Mexico’s drug cartels. But this would be ineffective, because curbing the cartels' power requires exposing their connections to the ruling Morena party.

item.title: The Biggest Mistake Warsh Could Make
item.description: Donald Trump's nominee for US Federal Reserve chair, Kevin Warsh, appears to be well qualified to respond effectively to the AI revolution. But his stated commitment to shrinking the Fed's bloated balance sheet could increase the risk of a bond market-induced financial crisis.

item.title: Trump Is No Game Theorist
item.description: US President Donald Trump seems to think that he can impose high tariffs on other economies, such as China, without facing retaliation, thereby securing huge gains for the US. But as game theory – in particular, the prisoner's dilemma – shows, the more likely outcome is that both sides will end up worse off.

item.title: India’s Middle-Power Dilemma
item.description: Many hope that India will participate in a coalition of middle powers to uphold a rule-based international order. But it will take time for the country’s foreign-policy establishment to move away from “strategic autonomy” as a guiding principle, and recent US behavior has confirmed skeptics’ arguments that the West is unreliable.

item.title: New World Order or Bust
item.description: With Donald Trump gleefully destroying what remains of the old postwar international order, the world is a mess. But the answer is not to defend institutions that have lost their effectiveness and legitimacy; it is to create something better, starting with AI, where we can build from the ground up.

item.title: The Coming Crypto Apocalypse
item.description: The future of money and payments will feature gradual evolution, not the revolution that crypto-grifters promised. Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies’ latest plunge further underscores the highly volatile nature of this pseudo-asset class; one only hopes that policymakers will wake up to the risks before it’s too late.

item.title: Financialization Won’t Improve Global Health
item.description: Rather than address the weaknesses of the grant-based approach to global health financing, donors want to scrap it in favor of instruments that mobilize more private capital. But this new architecture distorts the risk landscape in ways that socialize losses, while privatizing profits and control.

item.title: Markets Are Shrugging Off Uncertainty
item.description: Despite all the geopolitical and policy volatility that has marked the start of 2026, most key metrics of financial-market uncertainty have been immune to the state of the world. Either political sentiment and media narratives are overblown, or markets are whistling past the graveyard.

item.title: The ICEmen Killeth
item.description: So long as ICE agents, in their zeal to fulfill deportation quotas, targeted Hispanics or people of color, most white Americans did not fear for their safety, even if they deplored such tactics. But the murder by federal officers of two white US citizens at close range changes that, and the public backlash won’t fade soon.

item.title: America’s Mad Emperor
item.description: Every "logical" explanation that has been applied to US President Donald Trump's unhinged behavior over the years has proven inadequate. At this point, detractors and former supporters alike are recognizing that Trump's words and deeds can be explained by only one thing: mental derangement.

item.title: Penicillin and American Power
item.description: Technological leadership is often framed as a matter of singular breakthroughs rather than institutional capacity. But the rapid development of penicillin during World War II shows that coordinated public leadership, strong research institutions, and a dynamic private sector produce results no other innovation system can achieve.

item.title: Our Tariff-Era Dollar, Your Problem
item.description: The greenback’s effective depreciation on the trade side and its continued stability on the financial side will likely not last forever, at which point the US economy could be forced into a painful rebalancing. But until that day arrives, non-US economies should not assume that a weaker dollar will deliver the usual relief.

item.title: The Impact of Trump’s Tariffs on Latin America
item.description: The Latin American and Caribbean region has weathered the increase in US import tariffs relatively well, although certain countries and sectors have been more affected than others. But the more fraught global trade environment has underscored the need to deepen ties with regional and extra-regional partners.

item.title: The Middle-Power Dilemma
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney's call for the rest of the world to join forces in managing a new era of economic and geopolitical turmoil will certainly resonate with national leaders worldwide. But the path to unity among middle powers is fraught, because interests within such a broad grouping rarely align.

item.title: When Misinformation Kills
item.description: Disregard for scientific evidence by opponents of vaccination, led by US Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert F. Kennedy Jr., is producing exactly the harms experts predicted: disease outbreaks, preventable deaths, and the reversal of decades of progress in public health. The consequences could become truly catastrophic.

item.title: A United Front to Tame Trump
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s foreign policy rests on contempt for longstanding allies and a belief that force alone matters in international affairs. The path forward, as Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney argued in Davos, lies in midsize democracies banding together to preserve what remains of the postwar order.
